articles.headline: U.S. Moves Closer to Filing Sweeping Antitrust Case Against Apple
articles.snippet: Justice Department officials are in the late stages of investigating the iPhone maker, focusing on how Apple has used its other products and services to defend against threats to its core business.
articles.abstract: Justice Department officials are in the late stages of investigating the iPhone maker, focusing on how Apple has used its other products and services to defend against threats to its core business.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is in the late stages of an investigation into Apple and could file a sweeping antitrust case taking aim at the company’s strategies to protect the dominance of the iPhone as soon as the first half of this year, said three people with knowledge of the matter.
articles.byline: By David McCabe and Tripp Mickle

articles.headline: Three Years After Jan. 6, Trump’s Immunity Claims to Take Center Stage
articles.snippet: An appeals court will hear arguments on Tuesday over the former president’s attempt to shut down the federal election case. Much is riding on how — and how quickly — the issue is decided.
articles.abstract: An appeals court will hear arguments on Tuesday over the former president’s attempt to shut down the federal election case. Much is riding on how — and how quickly — the issue is decided.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three years after a mob of his supporters stormed the Capitol, former President Donald J. Trump will make his latest and potentially most consequential argument in the coming week for why he should not be held responsible for seeking to overturn the 2020 election.
articles.byline: By Alan Feuer and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Supreme Court to Decide Whether Trump Is Eligible for Colorado Ballot
articles.snippet: The Colorado Supreme Court ruled last month that the former president could not appear on the state’s Republican primary ballot because he had engaged in insurrection.
articles.abstract: The Colorado Supreme Court ruled last month that the former president could not appear on the state’s Republican primary ballot because he had engaged in insurrection.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to decide whether former President Donald J. Trump is eligible for Colorado’s Republican primary ballot, thrusting the justices into a pivotal role that could alter the course of this year’s presidential election.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak

articles.headline: Joseph Lelyveld, Former Top Editor of The New York Times, Dies at 86
articles.snippet: As executive editor from 1994 to 2001, he oversaw a period of growth, expanding national and international readerships, creating new sections and ushering in the digital age with a Times website.
articles.abstract: As executive editor from 1994 to 2001, he oversaw a period of growth, expanding national and international readerships, creating new sections and ushering in the digital age with a Times website.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joseph Lelyveld, a former executive editor and foreign correspondent for The New York Times, who won the 1986 Pulitzer Prize for nonfiction for his book “Move Your Shadow: South Africa, Black and White,” died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.
articles.byline: By Robert D. McFadden

articles.headline: F.A.A. Orders Airlines to Ground Some Boeing 737 Max 9 Jets After Midair ‘Incident’
articles.snippet: An Alaska Airlines plane made an emergency landing at the Portland, Ore., international airport on Friday after losing a chunk of its body, terrifying passengers.
articles.abstract: An Alaska Airlines plane made an emergency landing at the Portland, Ore., international airport on Friday after losing a chunk of its body, terrifying passengers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration on Saturday ordered U.S. airlines to stop using some Boeing 737 Max 9 planes until they are inspected, less than a day after one of those planes lost a chunk of its body in midair “with an extremely loud pop,” terrifying passengers before the jet safely returned to ground.
articles.byline: By John Yoon, Victoria Kim, Orlando Mayorquin, Niraj Chokshi and Mark Walker

articles.headline: As Gaza Losses Mount Under Strikes, Dignified Burials Are Another Casualty
articles.snippet: “The lucky are those who have someone to bury them when they die,” Dr. Mohammad Abu Moussa, a radiologist at one Gaza hospital, said of those killed by Israeli airstrikes.
articles.abstract: “The lucky are those who have someone to bury them when they die,” Dr. Mohammad Abu Moussa, a radiologist at one Gaza hospital, said of those killed by Israeli airstrikes.
articles.lead_paragraph: For four days, Kareem Sabawi’s body lay wrapped in a blanket in a cold, empty apartment as his family sheltered nearby. He was killed during intense Israeli bombardment near his family home, his father and mother said, and in the days that followed, it was too dangerous to step outside and lay their 10-year-old child to rest.
articles.byline: By Raja Abdulrahim, Samar Abu Elouf and Yousef Masoud

articles.headline: U.S. News Makes Money From Some of Its Biggest Critics: Colleges
articles.snippet: U.S. News sells “badges” to colleges, so they can promote their rankings — whether they are 1st, 10th or much, much lower.
articles.abstract: U.S. News sells “badges” to colleges, so they can promote their rankings — whether they are 1st, 10th or much, much lower.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jonathan Henry, a vice president at the University of Maine at Augusta, is hoping that an email will arrive this month. He is also sort of dreading it.
articles.byline: By Alan Blinder

articles.headline: How Harvard’s Board Broke Up With Claudine Gay
articles.snippet: Facing intense pressure, it went from standing behind her as the university’s president to pushing her out within weeks.
articles.abstract: Facing intense pressure, it went from standing behind her as the university’s president to pushing her out within weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: ​Claudine Gay was in Rome on a family vacation on Dec. 27 when Penny Pritzker, the leader of Harvard University’s governing board, called to ask: Did she think there was a path forward with her as the school’s president?
articles.byline: By Maureen Farrell and Rob Copeland

articles.headline: Red Sea Attacks Leave Shipping Companies With Difficult Choices
articles.snippet: Attacks on two dozen ships since November are forcing shipping lines to figure out whether and when to skip the Suez Canal and send vessels on longer voyages around Africa.
articles.abstract: Attacks on two dozen ships since November are forcing shipping lines to figure out whether and when to skip the Suez Canal and send vessels on longer voyages around Africa.
articles.lead_paragraph: The shipping companies that move goods on one of the world’s busiest trade routes for factories, stores, car dealerships and other businesses face an excruciating decision.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: In Frothy Awards Season, What Role Will Israel-Hamas War Play?
articles.snippet: Stars are increasingly vocal about political issues, but the Mideast conflict has divided Hollywood, magnifying the choice of whether to discuss the topic or remain silent.
articles.abstract: Stars are increasingly vocal about political issues, but the Mideast conflict has divided Hollywood, magnifying the choice of whether to discuss the topic or remain silent.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Hollywood heads into the heart of its awards season — a three-month orgy of frothy self-celebration and pop culture glamour — celebrities and their handlers find themselves with a serious decision to make: what, if anything, to say about the Israel-Hamas war.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: American Unions Long Backed Israel. Now, Some Are Protesting It.
articles.snippet: The shift reflects a broader generational change, and has exposed philosophical rifts in the labor movement about what the purpose of a union ought to be.
articles.abstract: The shift reflects a broader generational change, and has exposed philosophical rifts in the labor movement about what the purpose of a union ought to be.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Why are we here?” said Brandon Mancilla, a leader with the United Automobile Workers. Mr. Mancilla faced a crowd of hundreds of union members gathered on the steps of the New York Public Library’s Fifth Avenue branch, huddling against the cold as they rallied for a cease-fire in Gaza.
articles.byline: By Emma Goldberg and Santul Nerkar

articles.headline: Marijuana Buyers From Texas Fuel a ‘Little Amsterdam’ in New Mexico
articles.snippet: Sunland Park, along the Rio Grande, has joined the ranks of U.S. cities transformed by state cannabis laws. But the good times may not last forever.
articles.abstract: Sunland Park, along the Rio Grande, has joined the ranks of U.S. cities transformed by state cannabis laws. But the good times may not last forever.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a desert valley along the Rio Grande in New Mexico, the city of Sunland Park has generally offered few amenities for its roughly 17,000 residents. No large grocery store. Few shops. Little to offer those uninterested in the racetrack casino or a hike to the gigantic cross of Cristo Del Rey that looms from a nearby mountaintop.
articles.byline: By J. David Goodman and Erin Schaff

articles.headline: Blessing of Same-Sex Couples Rankles Africa’s Catholics
articles.snippet: It is out of step with the continent’s values, many bishops say, and threatens to derail expansion in the church’s fastest growing region in the world.
articles.abstract: It is out of step with the continent’s values, many bishops say, and threatens to derail expansion in the church’s fastest growing region in the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Vatican’s recent declaration allowing the blessing of same-sex couples caused a stir around the globe, but perhaps most of all in Africa, a rising center of the Roman Catholic Church’s future. In one statement after the next, bishops in several countries spoke of the fear and confusion the declaration has caused among their flocks, and said it was out of step with the continent’s culture and values.
articles.byline: By John Eligon

articles.headline: Writing Checks Can Be Risky. Here’s How to Protect Yourself.
articles.snippet: Should you keep a separate checking account for writing checks? Is there a specific pen you should use? We answer some reader questions.
articles.abstract: Should you keep a separate checking account for writing checks? Is there a specific pen you should use? We answer some reader questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Typewriters vanished, and then cassette tapes and encyclopedias did, too. But paper checks are one piece of our analog past that persists.
articles.byline: By Tara Siegel Bernard

articles.headline: Japanese Company’s Bid for U.S. Steel Tests Biden’s Industrial Policy
articles.snippet: The president is under pressure from Democrats and Republicans to block the sale to Japan’s Nippon Steel, which could upset a key foreign ally.
articles.abstract: The president is under pressure from Democrats and Republicans to block the sale to Japan’s Nippon Steel, which could upset a key foreign ally.
articles.lead_paragraph: U.S. Steel is an iconic example of the lost manufacturing muscle that President Biden says his economic policies will bring back to the United States.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: With Shutdown Looming, House and Senate Leaders Agree on Spending Levels
articles.snippet: Despite the deal, time is short to assemble and pass legislation putting the agreement in force before a Jan. 19 deadline.
articles.abstract: Despite the deal, time is short to assemble and pass legislation putting the agreement in force before a Jan. 19 deadline.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senate and House leaders announced on Sunday that they had struck an overarching agreement on 2024 government funding, but it was not clear whether they would be able to cement the deal and pass it into law in time to avert a partial government shutdown in less than two weeks.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse

articles.headline: From Lebanon to the Red Sea, a Broader Conflict With Iran Looms
articles.snippet: With its proxies attacking from many vantage points and its nuclear program suddenly revived, Iran is posing a new challenge to the West — this time with Russia and China on its side.
articles.abstract: With its proxies attacking from many vantage points and its nuclear program suddenly revived, Iran is posing a new challenge to the West — this time with Russia and China on its side.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden and his top national security aides believed last summer that the chances of conflict with Iran and its proxies were well contained.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Boeing Max 9 Jets Remain Grounded as Airlines Await Inspection Instructions
articles.snippet: Two days after a chunk of the fuselage blew out of one of the planes, the F.A.A. and the aircraft maker are still negotiating what to tell the airlines to do.
articles.abstract: Two days after a chunk of the fuselage blew out of one of the planes, the F.A.A. and the aircraft maker are still negotiating what to tell the airlines to do.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Boeing passenger jet model, the 737 Max 9, remained grounded in the United States on Sunday as airlines awaited instructions from the plane maker and the Federal Aviation Administration on how to inspect the planes and resume service, two days after a harrowing flight raised concerns about the jet.
articles.byline: By Niraj Chokshi

articles.headline: Dark Corners of the Web Offer a Glimpse at A.I.’s Nefarious Future
articles.snippet: In the hands of anonymous internet users, A.I. tools can create waves of harassing and racist material. It’s already happening on the anonymous message board 4chan.
articles.abstract: In the hands of anonymous internet users, A.I. tools can create waves of harassing and racist material. It’s already happening on the anonymous message board 4chan.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Louisiana parole board met in October to discuss the potential release of a convicted murderer, it called on a doctor with years of experience in mental health to talk about the inmate.
articles.byline: By Stuart A. Thompson

articles.headline: Trump Is Connecting With a Different Type of Evangelical Voter
articles.snippet: They are not just the churchgoing, conservative activists who once dominated the G.O.P.
articles.abstract: They are not just the churchgoing, conservative activists who once dominated the G.O.P.
articles.lead_paragraph: Karen Johnson went to her Lutheran church so regularly as a child that she won a perfect attendance award. As an adult, she taught Sunday school. But these days, Ms. Johnson, a 67-year-old counter attendant at a slot-machine parlor, no longer goes to church.
articles.byline: By Ruth Graham and Charles Homans

articles.headline: Robots Learn, Chatbots Visualize: How 2024 Will Be A.I.’s ‘Leap Forward’
articles.snippet: A.I. is set to advance at a rapid rate, becoming more powerful and spreading into the physical world.
articles.abstract: A.I. is set to advance at a rapid rate, becoming more powerful and spreading into the physical world.
articles.lead_paragraph: At an event in San Francisco in November, Sam Altman, the chief executive of the artificial intelligence company OpenAI, was asked what surprises the field would bring in 2024.
articles.byline: By Cade Metz

articles.headline: Exhausted, on the Defensive and at ‘Hell’s Gate’ in Ukraine
articles.snippet: The country’s forces along a broad stretch of the front say that, with Russia pushing forward, the war has never been so dangerous.
articles.abstract: The country’s forces along a broad stretch of the front say that, with Russia pushing forward, the war has never been so dangerous.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZAPORIZHZHIA REGION, Ukraine — Under the cover of darkness, leaning forward under the weight of packs and rifles, a squad of soldiers walked along a muddy lane and slipped into a village house.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall, Vladyslav Golovin and Mauricio Lima
